flashcards.front: For regular -ER verbs in the present tense, the endings for Je, Tu, Il/Elle/On are -e, -es, -e.
flashcards.back:
Je parle français. (I speak French.)
Tu regardes la télévision. (You watch TV.)
Elle écoute la musique. (She listens to music.)

metadata.rule: For regular -ER verbs in the present tense, the endings for Je, Tu, Il/Elle/On are -e, -es, -e.
examples: Je parle français. (I speak French.)
Tu regardes la télévision. (You watch TV.)
Elle écoute la musique. (She listens to music.)
exceptions: Aller (to go) is highly irregular.

flashcards.front: For regular -ER verbs in the present tense, the endings for Nous, Vous, Ils/Elles are -ons, -ez, -ent.
flashcards.back:
Nous mangeons à midi. (We eat at noon.)
Vous travaillez beaucoup. (You work a lot.)
Ils aiment le chocolat. (They like chocolate.)

metadata.rule: For regular -ER verbs in the present tense, the endings for Nous, Vous, Ils/Elles are -ons, -ez, -ent.
examples: Nous mangeons à midi. (We eat at noon.)
Vous travaillez beaucoup. (You work a lot.)
Ils aiment le chocolat. (They like chocolate.)
exceptions: The '-ent' ending is silent.

flashcards.front: To form a negative sentence, place 'ne' before the conjugated verb and 'pas' after it.
flashcards.back:
Je ne parle pas espagnol. (I do not speak Spanish.)
Nous n'étudions pas ce soir. (We are not studying tonight.)

metadata.rule: To form a negative sentence, place 'ne' before the conjugated verb and 'pas' after it.
examples: Je ne parle pas espagnol. (I do not speak Spanish.)
Nous n'étudions pas ce soir. (We are not studying tonight.)
exceptions: If the verb starts with a vowel or silent 'h', 'ne' becomes 'n''.

flashcards.front: In French, the definite article 'le' is used before singular masculine nouns.
flashcards.back:
Le livre est rouge. (The book is red.)
J'aime le sport. (I like sport.)

metadata.rule: In French, the definite article 'le' is used before singular masculine nouns.
examples: Le livre est rouge. (The book is red.)
J'aime le sport. (I like sport.)
exceptions: If the noun starts with a vowel, use 'l'' (e.g., l'homme).

flashcards.front: The definite article 'la' is used before singular feminine nouns.
flashcards.back:
La table est grande. (The table is big.)
Où est la clé? (Where is the key?)

metadata.rule: The definite article 'la' is used before singular feminine nouns.
examples: La table est grande. (The table is big.)
Où est la clé? (Where is the key?)
exceptions: If the noun starts with a vowel, use 'l'' (e.g., l'école).

flashcards.front: The definite article 'les' is used before all plural nouns, regardless of gender.
flashcards.back:
Les étudiants sont ici. (The students are here.)
J'achète les pommes. (I buy the apples.)

metadata.rule: The definite article 'les' is used before all plural nouns, regardless of gender.
examples: Les étudiants sont ici. (The students are here.)
J'achète les pommes. (I buy the apples.)
exceptions: None.

flashcards.front: The indefinite article 'un' means 'a' or 'an' and is used before singular masculine nouns.
flashcards.back:
J'ai un chien. (I have a dog.)
C'est un problème. (It is a problem.)

metadata.rule: The indefinite article 'un' means 'a' or 'an' and is used before singular masculine nouns.
examples: J'ai un chien. (I have a dog.)
C'est un problème. (It is a problem.)
exceptions: None.

flashcards.front: The indefinite article 'des' means 'some' and is used before all plural nouns.
flashcards.back:
Il y a des livres sur la table. (There are some books on the table.)
Nous achetons des fleurs. (We buy some flowers.)

metadata.rule: The indefinite article 'des' means 'some' and is used before all plural nouns.
examples: Il y a des livres sur la table. (There are some books on the table.)
Nous achetons des fleurs. (We buy some flowers.)
exceptions: In negative sentences, 'des' often changes to 'de' or 'd''.

flashcards.front: For regular -IR verbs (like 'finir'), the present tense endings for Je, Tu, Il/Elle/On are -is, -is, -it.
flashcards.back:
Je finis mes devoirs. (I finish my homework.)
Tu choisis une couleur. (You choose a color.)
Il réagit bien. (He reacts well.)

metadata.rule: For regular -IR verbs (like 'finir'), the present tense endings for Je, Tu, Il/Elle/On are -is, -is, -it.
examples: Je finis mes devoirs. (I finish my homework.)
Tu choisis une couleur. (You choose a color.)
Il réagit bien. (He reacts well.)
exceptions: Many common -IR verbs (like Venir, Sortir) are irregular.

flashcards.front: For regular -IR verbs, the present tense endings for Nous, Vous, Ils/Elles include the 'ss' suffix: -issons, -issez, -issent.
flashcards.back:
Nous finissons le repas. (We finish the meal.)
Vous réussissez à l'examen. (You succeed on the exam.)
Elles punissent les enfants. (They punish the children.)

metadata.rule: For regular -IR verbs, the present tense endings for Nous, Vous, Ils/Elles include the 'ss' suffix: -issons, -issez, -issent.
examples: Nous finissons le repas. (We finish the meal.)
Vous réussissez à l'examen. (You succeed on the exam.)
Elles punissent les enfants. (They punish the children.)
exceptions: The '-issent' ending is silent.

flashcards.front: For regular -RE verbs (like 'vendre'), the present tense endings for Je, Tu, Il/Elle/On are -s, -s, (nothing).
flashcards.back:
Je vends ma maison. (I sell my house.)
Tu attends le bus. (You wait for the bus.)
Il répond à la question. (He answers the question.)

metadata.rule: For regular -RE verbs (like 'vendre'), the present tense endings for Je, Tu, Il/Elle/On are -s, -s, (nothing).
examples: Je vends ma maison. (I sell my house.)
Tu attends le bus. (You wait for the bus.)
Il répond à la question. (He answers the question.)
exceptions: Prendre (to take) is a common irregular -RE verb.

flashcards.front: For regular -RE verbs, the present tense endings for Nous, Vous, Ils/Elles are -ons, -ez, -ent.
flashcards.back:
Nous perdons le match. (We lose the match.)
Vous rendez les clés. (You return the keys.)
Elles entendent du bruit. (They hear noise.)

metadata.rule: For regular -RE verbs, the present tense endings for Nous, Vous, Ils/Elles are -ons, -ez, -ent.
examples: Nous perdons le match. (We lose the match.)
Vous rendez les clés. (You return the keys.)
Elles entendent du bruit. (They hear noise.)
exceptions: The '-ent' ending is silent.

flashcards.front: The basic word order in a French declarative sentence is Subject-Verb-Object (SVO).
flashcards.back:
Marie boit du café. (Marie drinks coffee.)
Nous visitons Paris. (We visit Paris.)

metadata.rule: The basic word order in a French declarative sentence is Subject-Verb-Object (SVO).
examples: Marie boit du café. (Marie drinks coffee.)
Nous visitons Paris. (We visit Paris.)
exceptions: Pronouns (like 'le', 'la', 'me', 'te') usually precede the verb.

flashcards.front: To form a simple Yes/No question, use rising intonation at the end of a declarative sentence.
flashcards.back:
Tu travailles aujourd'hui ? (You are working today?)
Vous parlez français ? (You speak French?)

metadata.rule: To form a simple Yes/No question, use rising intonation at the end of a declarative sentence.
examples: Tu travailles aujourd'hui ? (You are working today?)
Vous parlez français ? (You speak French?)
exceptions: This is the most informal way; 'Est-ce que' is more formal.

flashcards.front: Nouns that end in -e (especially -tion, -sion, -té) are generally feminine.
flashcards.back:
La voiture (the car)
La télévision (the television)
La liberté (liberty)

metadata.rule: Nouns that end in -e (especially -tion, -sion, -té) are generally feminine.
examples: La voiture (the car)
La télévision (the television)
La liberté (liberty)
exceptions: Le problème, Le musée, Le téléphone (Masculine exceptions).

flashcards.front: Nouns that end in consonants (excluding -tion, -sion) or vowels (excluding -e) are often masculine.
flashcards.back:
Le fromage (the cheese)
Le restaurant (the restaurant)
Le cadeau (the gift)

metadata.rule: Nouns that end in consonants (excluding -tion, -sion) or vowels (excluding -e) are often masculine.
examples: Le fromage (the cheese)
Le restaurant (the restaurant)
Le cadeau (the gift)
exceptions: La main (the hand), La fleur (the flower) (Feminine exceptions).

flashcards.front: To make most nouns plural, add an -s to the end of the singular form.
flashcards.back:
Un ami → Des amis (A friend → Some friends)
La pomme → Les pommes (The apple → The apples)

metadata.rule: To make most nouns plural, add an -s to the end of the singular form.
examples: Un ami → Des amis (A friend → Some friends)
La pomme → Les pommes (The apple → The apples)
exceptions: Nouns ending in -s, -x, -z remain unchanged (e.g., un nez → des nez).
Nouns ending in -al change to -aux (e.g., un cheval → des chevaux).

flashcards.front: Adjectives must agree in gender with the noun they modify. To form the feminine, add an -e to the masculine singular form.
flashcards.back:
Un petit garçon. (A small boy.)
Une petite fille. (A small girl.)

metadata.rule: Adjectives must agree in gender with the noun they modify. To form the feminine, add an -e to the masculine singular form.
examples: Un petit garçon. (A small boy.)
Une petite fille. (A small girl.)
exceptions: If the masculine already ends in -e, no change is made (e.g., rapide).

flashcards.front: Most descriptive adjectives are placed *after* the noun they modify.
flashcards.back:
J'ai une voiture rouge. (I have a red car.)
C'est un film intéressant. (It is an interesting movie.)

metadata.rule: Most descriptive adjectives are placed *after* the noun they modify.
examples: J'ai une voiture rouge. (I have a red car.)
C'est un film intéressant. (It is an interesting movie.)
exceptions: BAGS adjectives (Beauty, Age, Goodness, Size) precede the noun (e.g., un grand homme).

flashcards.front: When conjugating -ER verbs that end in -GER (like manger), an 'e' is added before the -ons ending for 'Nous' to keep the soft 'g' sound.
flashcards.back:
Je mange. (I eat.)
Nous mangeons. (We eat.)

metadata.rule: When conjugating -ER verbs that end in -GER (like manger), an 'e' is added before the -ons ending for 'Nous' to keep the soft 'g' sound.
examples: Je mange. (I eat.)
Nous mangeons. (We eat.)
exceptions: This only applies to the 'Nous' form.

flashcards.front: When conjugating -ER verbs that end in -CER (like commencer), the 'c' changes to 'ç' before the -ons ending for 'Nous' to keep the soft 'c' sound.
flashcards.back:
Il commence. (He starts.)
Nous commençons. (We start.)

metadata.rule: When conjugating -ER verbs that end in -CER (like commencer), the 'c' changes to 'ç' before the -ons ending for 'Nous' to keep the soft 'c' sound.
examples: Il commence. (He starts.)
Nous commençons. (We start.)
exceptions: This only applies to the 'Nous' form.

flashcards.front: The verb 'Avoir' (to have) is highly irregular and essential for A1 communication.
flashcards.back:
J'ai faim. (I am hungry.)
Tu as quel âge? (How old are you?)
Elle a un chat. (She has a cat.)

metadata.rule: The verb 'Avoir' (to have) is highly irregular and essential for A1 communication.
examples: J'ai faim. (I am hungry.)
Tu as quel âge? (How old are you?)
Elle a un chat. (She has a cat.)
exceptions: The full conjugation is irregular (Nous avons, Vous avez, Ils ont).

flashcards.front: The verb 'Être' (to be) is highly irregular and essential for description and location.
flashcards.back:
Je suis étudiant. (I am a student.)
Tu es fatigué. (You are tired.)
Il est ici. (He is here.)

metadata.rule: The verb 'Être' (to be) is highly irregular and essential for description and location.
metadata.pattern: Je suis, Tu es, Il/Elle/On est
examples: Je suis étudiant. (I am a student.)
Tu es fatigué. (You are tired.)
Il est ici. (He is here.)
exceptions: The full conjugation is irregular (Nous sommes, Vous êtes, Ils sont).

flashcards.front: The verb 'Aller' (to go) is highly irregular, even though it ends in -ER.
flashcards.back:
Je vais au marché. (I go to the market.)
Elle va bien. (She is doing well.)

metadata.rule: The verb 'Aller' (to go) is highly irregular, even though it ends in -ER.
metadata.pattern: Je vais, Tu vas, Il/Elle/On va
examples: Je vais au marché. (I go to the market.)
Elle va bien. (She is doing well.)
exceptions: The 'Nous' form is 'Nous allons'.

flashcards.front: In negation, if the verb starts with a vowel (A, E, I, O, U) or a silent 'H', 'ne' contracts to 'n''.
flashcards.back:
Je n'aime pas le froid. (I don't like the cold.)
Il n'habite pas ici. (He doesn't live here.)

metadata.rule: In negation, if the verb starts with a vowel (A, E, I, O, U) or a silent 'H', 'ne' contracts to 'n''.
examples: Je n'aime pas le froid. (I don't like the cold.)
Il n'habite pas ici. (He doesn't live here.)
exceptions: None.

flashcards.front: When asking questions using 'Est-ce que', the word order remains SVO (Subject-Verb-Object).
flashcards.back:
Est-ce que tu étudies le soir ? (Do you study in the evening?)
Est-ce qu'elle mange de la viande ? (Does she eat meat?)

metadata.rule: When asking questions using 'Est-ce que', the word order remains SVO (Subject-Verb-Object).
examples: Est-ce que tu étudies le soir ? (Do you study in the evening?)
Est-ce qu'elle mange de la viande ? (Does she eat meat?)
exceptions: The 'e' in 'que' drops before a vowel (qu'il, qu'elle).

flashcards.front: Possessive adjectives (mon, ma, mes) agree in gender and number with the noun they modify, not the owner.
flashcards.back:
C'est mon livre (masc. noun). (It is my book.)
C'est ma voiture (fem. noun). (It is my car.)

metadata.rule: Possessive adjectives (mon, ma, mes) agree in gender and number with the noun they modify, not the owner.
examples: C'est mon livre (masc. noun). (It is my book.)
C'est ma voiture (fem. noun). (It is my car.)
exceptions: Use 'mon' before a feminine singular noun if it starts with a vowel (e.g., mon amie).

flashcards.front: The preposition 'à' (to/at) contracts with the definite articles 'le' and 'les'.
flashcards.back:
Je parle au professeur. (I speak to the teacher.)
Nous allons aux États-Unis. (We go to the USA.)

metadata.rule: The preposition 'à' (to/at) contracts with the definite articles 'le' and 'les'.
metadata.pattern: à + le = au; à + les = aux
examples: Je parle au professeur. (I speak to the teacher.)
Nous allons aux États-Unis. (We go to the USA.)
exceptions: It does not contract with 'la' or 'l'' (à la, à l').

flashcards.front: The preposition 'de' (of/from) contracts with the definite articles 'le' and 'les'.
flashcards.back:
C'est le livre du garçon. (It is the boy's book.)
Je viens des Pays-Bas. (I come from the Netherlands.)

metadata.rule: The preposition 'de' (of/from) contracts with the definite articles 'le' and 'les'.
metadata.pattern: de + le = du; de + les = des
examples: C'est le livre du garçon. (It is the boy's book.)
Je viens des Pays-Bas. (I come from the Netherlands.)
exceptions: It does not contract with 'la' or 'l'' (de la, de l').
